div.p: Hewſon Reduc'd: OR, THE SHOOMAKER RETURN'D TO HIS TRADE.
BEING A SHOW, Wherein is repreſented the HONESTY, IN OFFENSIVENESS, and INGENUITY of that PROFESSION, when 'tis kept within its own Bounds, and goes not beyond the Laſt.
Written by a true Friend to the gentle CRAFT.
LONDON, Printed for Auſtine Rice in St. Pauls Church-yard. 166 •

list.head: Actorum nomina.
list.item: PROLOGUS, a Shoomaker bringing in Boots, Shooes, Slippers, and Pumps.

div.p:
You muſt underſtand that a Shoomaker is the Show-maker. I have been two daies making a pair of Boots, Shooes, Slippers, and Pumps; and they had not been done yet, but that I went through ſtich with Aule. Theſe Boots methinks ſhould fit any man, but thoſe that are too big in the Calf; theſe Shooes will pinch no man, but he that is troubled with Corns: theſe Pumps will fit any man, but thoſe that hold Dancing ſuperſtitious; theſe Slippers will pleaſe any man I am ſure, but he that is out at the Heels: however I'le go preſently and put them on; only thus much I'le ſpeak in my own defence.
Muſe not we ſpeak of ſuch like things as theſe,
We ſhallow Wits wade not above the knees:
Theſe lowly things I hope will not diſtaſt;
Men of our Trade go not beyond the Laſt.

sp.p: HE that hath ſerved in the Office of a Footman ſo long as I have done, though ne're ſo light at firſt, (ere the year go about) ſhall be a heavy man. Sure I was born to run as long as I breath: but if the way had not been ſo dirty, I would have ſhewed my Maſter a fair pair of Heels; but if he ſend me again to run ſuch a way, I will run quite away. I have come to day further, than I hope I ſhall go to morrow: for Mr. Boot will be ſure to have his Liquor before he goes out of Town. My Maſter hath ſent me before to provide his Inne, but I'le meet with him anon for't; I'le go to the Sign of the Leg, there is my old friend Slipper: The ſign of the Leg is either in Shoomaker Row, or in Hoſier Lane.

sp.speaker: Pump.
sp.p: Shoomaker Row, or in Hoſier Lane? I ſhall know by this it is a Leg in Print, and ſee by good luck I have ſtumbled of the Leg; firſt in ſtep: What, ſo hoe, Chamberlain?

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: Anon, anon, Sir (intus.)

sp.speaker: Pump.
sp.p: It is the trick of theſe Chamberlains never to do any thing at the firſt word: What, Chamberlain, Come away.

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: Anon, anon, Sir; What, my old Companion pump, with whom I dwelt, ſo long? Let Slip. embrace thee.

sp.speaker: Pump.
sp.p: I am glad old Slip. to ſee thy heels at liberty, but I'le tell thee what, my Maſter Boot is at the next Town by this time.

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: He ſhall be welcome; in faith he is a good Gueſt, he'l come off roundly, and therefore Slip. will be alwaies ready for him.

sp.speaker: Pump.
sp.p: Come, let's ſee a Chamber preſently.

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: I, preſently; I know Mr. Boot is a neat fellow, and therefore he ſhall have a very neat Chamber. Exit Slip.

sp.speaker: Pump.
sp.p: Make haſt again: I never felt my ſelf ſo weary in all my life; I perceive now poor Pump, thou art paſt the beſt, ſuch another Journey as this will quite wear thee out. Enter Slip.

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: I know Pump thou art dry, come follow me into the Room, and there Pump I'le give thee a ſlaſh.

sp.speaker: Pump.
sp.p: Do thy worſt: Pump will never refuſe good Liquor.

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: I think our Trades are both alike one the other, for Chamberlains and Footmen get their living by running up and down.

sp.speaker: Pump.
sp.p: Nay, ſoft, the Footman hath the better, for he may go before his Maſter.

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: Why, are not Chamberlains men of great calling? every one that hath to do with them, ſhall finde them men of good reckoning.

sp.speaker: Pump.
sp.p: Faith Slip. there you go o're me, and beſides this, Footmen are very provident, for be their Maſter ne're ſo wiſe, they muſt riſe betimes if they will over reach them.

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: Faith Chamberlains are as cunning, for they have alwaies a trick to deceive their Maſters, for if they be above, they will under-mine them, if below, they will be ſure to come over them.

sp.speaker: Pump.
sp.p: Well, Slipper, P. will not fall out with thee; we will drown our quarrels in this Glaſs of drink.

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: What? Mother Geers Round? one to another?

sp.speaker: Boot.
sp.p: Come Spur, where art thou?

sp.speaker: Spur.
sp.p: Hard at your heels, Sir.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Faith but for thee I ſhould not have got to my Journeys end to night.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: Faith Maſter we were fain to prick on hard: Spur did his beſt to ſet you forward.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: Well-ſaid Spur, I ſee that thou art all mettle.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: Yet as ſoon as you come to your Journeys end, you caſt me off.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: But yet thou haſt the wit to ſtick cloſe to me.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: I do it for your ſake, for you will never ride without me.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: This is one thing, I know thee truſty, for many times thou haſt fought up to the ears in blood for myſake.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: Nay, I would have you know my Service on foot too; for unleſs. I attend you, you can walk in no faſhion.

sp.speaker: Boot.
sp.p: But Spur, One thing I like not in thee, thou ſpoileſt all my Horſes, thou art a very ſore Rider.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: Why I am as good as Provender to your Horſes, I will ſtick cloſe to his Ribs.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: Let it be thy part to ſee my Horſes well curried, while I go call for my Lodging: What, Chamberlain? Exit Spur.

sp.speaker: Pump.
sp.p: O here is Mr. Boot, I know by his creeking Slipper: Now ſhew a ſlippery trick, and ſlip away the Jugg. (Exit Slip.) And I will pump for an anſwer for my Maſter. O Mr. Pump ſtoops as low as your feet to welcome you to the ſign of the Leg.

sp.speaker: Boot.
sp.p: Methinks you are ſomwhat fine, I doubt ſome body hath trim'd you ſince you came in.

sp.speaker: Pump.
sp.p: I muſt needs ſay your poor Vaſſal hath been veſſelling; I have been with Slipper and have ſet foot to foot and drunk hard.

sp.speaker: Boo.
sp.p: Theſe be your old tricks: as long as there is any ſtrong Beer to be had, Pump will drink no water. But what have you provided for my Supper?

sp.speaker: Pump.
sp.p: Faith I have clean forgotten, I ſpoke for ſomthing, but I know not what; Call up the Chamberlain, he knows more of my minde.

sp.speaker: Boot.
sp.p: Juſt ſuch a trick you ſerved me at Fluſhing when you were drunk.

sp.speaker: Pump.
sp.p: Maſter, if you will believe me, I was as ſober as I am now.

sp.speaker: Boo.
sp.p: 'Tis well you can be drunk and ſtand in't too. What, Chamberlain? Enter Slip.
Anon, Anon, Sir, What's your Worſhips pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: What did my man beſpeak for Supper.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: Three Juggs of Beer, and half a dram of Tobacco.

sp.speaker: Pump.
sp.p: St. St.

sp.speaker: Sli.
sp.p: O, I cry you mercy, I miſtook the Room.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: Do you not know what is provided for my Supper.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: Not very well, but whatſoever it is, it ſhall be ready for your Worſhip: But you ſhall be ſure of a meſs of Sallet Oyle, and a diſh of freſh Butter.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Very good.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: Nay, it ſhall be very good.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: In good time.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: Nay, you ſhall have it in very good time.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p:
Nay, good Sir, ſtand not ſo much upon your Pantoples, but anſwer me directly to one queſtion; Do
you not know one Mr. Shooe?

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, there be two of that name, the one a High-German, the other a Low-Countryman.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: I mean him that dwels in the Town.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: I know him well, he is a man of very good faſhion, and a continuall Houſekeeper.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: And I hear very good report of him, that Mr. Shooe is a very upright man.

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: And yet for all that he may go awry ſomtimes; and this is his fault, he loves to be greaſed often: But as I take it, heer comes the Gentleman. Enter Shooe and String.

sp.speaker: Shooe.
sp.p: String, Come tye my Shoe.

sp.speaker: Pum.
sp.p: What little go by the ground is that?

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: A Hang-by of Mr. Shooe; they call him Shooe-tye, a fellow that I am not beholding to: But Pump, farewel a while. (Exit Slip.)

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Slipper farewel. Pump will have a fling at you anon. Shooe, Sirrah, How doth my Coſin Stocking?

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Faith, Sir, He was lately a dying, but now they ſay, he is on the mending hand.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: Why, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: They ſay he took a grief, becauſe he ſtretcht himſelf for. Mr. Leg, and ſo brake.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: Well, if that be all, we'l have the matter taken up: But for my Neighbour Foot, what ſayes he?

sp.speaker: St.
sp.p: Marry Foot ſaith, he ſcorneth to be kept in by your Vows, as he is a part of the Body Politick, and a Member of the Commonwealth; he will do his beſt to tread you under foot.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: Alas, poor wretch, I took him in, when he might have ſtood and cool'd his Toes: But let him go whither he will, he ſhall never come into my latch again. But is not yonder Mr. Boot?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: Mr. Shoe.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: Your poor friend: Shoe would do Mr. Boot any ſervice, One that will ſpend life and limb to do you ſervice: But methinks Mr. Boot you look ſomwhat old, for you are full of wrinkles.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: Age and Travel will alter a man.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: I hope you have been no great Traveller.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: as great as any goes upon earth; for travel, Coriate could never come neer me.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: I think ſo, for Coriate went alwaies on foot, You travel on Horſeback. But what think you of Coriate's Book of his Travels?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: I ſuppoſe he took great pains, and travelled hard for it; but his Crudites I could never digeſt them; he cannot ſo much as paſs by a Walnut Tree, but he muſt have a fling at it: He can as well be hang'd as paſs by a Gibbet, and every pair of Gallows he removes, as if they were Hercules's Pillars: but becauſe he is my fellow-traveller, I'le let him paſs.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: But what ſay you to Mr. Mandevill? they ſay he went to the Worlds end, and then I am ſure none of you can go beyond him.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: I think ſo for lying, for he will go to a hair; He loſeth his hair in ſome hot skirmiſh, and then ſayes, he was burnt in going too neer the Sun.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: Faith it was a bold excuſe, and yet it was well enough: Put off, let us leave theſe Land-travellers for a company of dry fellows: Now for the Water-men, let us have an Oare in their Bote; What ſay you to Drake and Candiſh?

sp.speaker: Boot.
sp.p: Faith Candiſh made a good Voyage at the firſt, but was clean o're the ears ere he was aware the ſecond time, he had ſo engag'd himſelf, and ſo in the end proved a Caſt-away.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: It is an excellent thing for a Marriner to keep himſelf within Compaſs; but how ſped Drake?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: Drake was a wilde fellow, but before he had done, he ſo trounced the Spaniards, that he made them quake, quake.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: And theſe Seamen methinks ſhould ſtand beſt to their Tackling. But what's the reaſon theſe Puritans cannot abide them?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: I think it is becauſe they hate the Sea of Rome.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: Or it is becauſe they uſe the Cardinals Windes.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: Or perhaps becauſe they hate the invention of Cards.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: Or becauſe they have a Pilot in their Company.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: I am partly of their minde; I have gone as far as any of them, but by my good will, Boot will never take water. But by this time, Mr. Shooe I think your heels do ake with ſtanding, therefore ſit down here, and I will unfold unto you the whole diſcourſe of my Travels in Print.

sp.speaker: String.
sp.p: Now while my Maſter and Mr. Boot are ſet at talk, I'le enter Complement with this finical Gentleman; Sir, your friend Shoeſtring had no ſooner got to ſee you, but he muſt needs ſalute you in the way of kindneſs.

sp.speaker: Pump.
sp.p: Sir, in reciprocal congratulation, I kiſs the very ſhadow of your Shooeſtring.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: I pray, Sir, let me crave your name.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Do then.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Then, Sir, with your good leave and liking, what's your name.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: My name is Water Pump, Sir,

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Very well: Water, I thought your name was Water, you look ſo thin on't; ſurely he that made your Trunks was a very good Taylor, he went ſo roundly to work.

sp.speaker: Pum.
sp.p: Why, Sirrah, I hope, Jack-ſawce, I may wear theſe Nocks in deſpight of your Noſe.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Surely you were a fortunate young man, you were lapt in your Mothers Smock, for ſhe hath given you one of her old Blankets.

sp.speaker: Pump.
sp.p: You harp too much upon one String, Shootye, though your Tongue be ne're ſo buſie about my Nocks; I do not think you can pull down my Breeches.

sp.speaker: St.
sp.p: Shite on your Breeches, I care not a fart for them.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Well I perceive ſhortly, if I ſhould ſtay ne're ſo long, you will never leave wagging: Well, I'le leave you to my fellow Spur. Exit.

sp.speaker: Spur.
sp.p: Good Oſtler, if ever you mean to curry favour with me, look well to my Horſes, and let them be well littered, or elſe I'le care not a ſtraw for you; do not play the freſh Serving-man with me: pour down their Provender before them, and let them try it out by the Teeth.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Mr. Bo. is a ſtrange man, he hath a pair of Serving-men look as if they were not fellows; one in his Nocks, and another in his Cloakbag: Pray, Sir, before—give me leave to ſpur you one queſtion.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: If you will give me leave to kick you an anſwer.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, what Countryman are you?

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: Northamptonſhire man, and I was born at Rowel.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: I had thought you had been a German; you are ſomthing a kin to Kickerman.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: I perceive you are a notable Slip-ſtring: but, ſirrah, is thy Maſter here?

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: What if he be, Spur hath nothing to do with him.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: O, He comes in good time, for all my Horſes want ſhoes.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: do not diſparage my Maſter, for I will not change with you without Boot.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: Nor I with you, for all the ſhooes in your Shop.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Go to, hold your peace, if Boot be ſo luſty, we'l have him ſtrapt.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: Boy, hold your prating, if Shoe flie out, I'le clowt him my ſelf: What is your Maſter but a Zitizen, and then he is but a Prentice at the moſt; And thy Maſter (ſaith String) is but a Traveller, and then he is a Journeyman.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: Shooe-tye hold your peace, or I'le hang you up for the ſign of the Roſe.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: I can tell you the Roſe is the beſt flower in my Maſters Garden. But I wonder Spur why you are ſo ſharp; for all your great Sword, if I once buckle with you, I'le leather your Hide.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p:
I hope my Sword troubleth not you; if you be ſo buſie Shooe-tye, take heed,
this is the great Sword that cut the Gordian knots.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: I could never tell why ſuch clowniſh Serving-men are ty'd to ſuch great Swords, unleſs it be when they fart they might touch cold iron.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: Sirrah, I'le tell you, wit • the point I'le prick a hole in your coat, and with the Hilt I'le pannel you about the pate.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: But ſtay, Sirrah, here comes your Maſter to take you off.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: Mr. Shooe, you and I come both from one houſe, for as Antiquaries ſay, we are lineally deſcended from Th • ng-castle.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: Nay, there Mr. Boot I think you are wide, for I heard ſome ſay, that our Anceſtors were born at Bulver-hide, but it is no great matter, it is certain we came both from one ſtock.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: But I forgot to tell you one thing as I paſſed by this Town ſide, I had much ado to 'ſcape this Tree: ſo coming along Francefa deep, I fell up to the top in a dirty hole, and was ſo bemired, that I was fain to get an Oſtler to make me clean.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: Bee-lady that was a foul miſchance.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: Nay, I can tell you Boot hath many of thoſe Voyages, for he hath gone through thick and thin.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: Well, now I ſee plainly before my face that you are a great Traveller, you excel Ʋlyſſes for all he was ſo long abroad, that when he came home his wife knew him not, no more then his Dog: and Aeneas though he was a true Trojan, yet may come far behinde you.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: As for Ʋlyſſes, Cirees made a very Hog-rubber of him; and for Aeneas, any Ape may do as much as he did.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: Good, Sir, may I entreat but one thing, that you would beſtow this Map on me.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: Mr. Shoe, I would be loath to ſtick with you for any thing, but you muſt pardon me, I ſhould not part with this Map for a world: but I think I have held you too long, therefore to winde up all in a word, after this rare diſcourſe, I will invite you to part of a bad Supper.

sp.speaker: Shooe,
sp.p: No, faith I mean to go another way.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: Nay, Mr. Sh. I will not be put off ſo.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p:
Nay, then good Mr. Boot lead you the way, I'le follow at an inch.
Exeunt Boot and Shoe.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: I hope you are ſomwhat cooler, you are not a hot Spur ſtill.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: No, faith, my little wagg, 'twas but a flouriſh: but why went my fellow Pump away?

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p:
It ſeems he had been drinking ſomwhat ſtiffly, and your Pump could not hold his water.
Enter Slipper, Jugg, and a Glaſs.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: What? how now Slipper, never without a Jugg of Beer in thy hand?

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: I, here you may ſee as in a glaſs the life that we Chamberlains lead.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Come, 'tis in a good hand, pray begin to ſombody.

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: Sirrah, you may be ſure I'le not begin to you, for I was never beholding to Shooe-tye.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: And that is that hath made you ſuch a looſe fellow.

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: Go-to String, you are a very wag-halter; here's to thee Spur, thou art all ſteel to the back.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: Come, I'le never refuſe Chamberlain; but I am half out of love with thoſe Oſtlers, one of them yeſter-night gave me ſuch a rub.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: What, a whole one?

sp.speaker: Spur.
sp.p: What elſe but a whole one:

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: was alwaies a dry Whorſon.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: And I have alwaies marked this in him, when Slipper was ſober he was in his plain faſhion, but when he is typſie he is alwaies in his turn-overs.

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: Well Shooe-tye if you uſe theſe tricks, you may chance come to be knit up: But I pray you, Sir, take off your liquor.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: Here Shooe-tye (he drinks) Troth I wonder at theſe Tapſters how they bear ſo much drink, ſuch another glaſs as this would make Spur's head turn round.

sp.speaker: Pump.
sp.p: I thought where I ſhould finde you, you muſt ſtand neſting here, while poor Pump muſt dance attendance; come away quickly, or my Maſter ſwears he'l have you all ſet in the Shoomakers ſtocks.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Faith, for my Maſter Shooe, I have him in a ſtring.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: For Mr. Boot I have ſerved him on and off a good while.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Faith, Pump thou ſtands as though thou hadſt neither life nor ſoul: will you drink?

sp.speaker: Pump.
sp.p: No, by no means, I had as liffe pour it into my ſhooes.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: I hope Pump you may be drawn by little and little.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Nay, if you be thereabout, I muſt take me to my heels. Exit.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: Though I care not for my Maſter, yet I love my Supper, therefore let's in, and after Supper wee? I have a Catch in the Chimney-corner.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Content. Exit.

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: Pray you, Sir, while you ſing the Song let me bear the burden: I, take the Cloak-bag.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: Thank you heartily, 'tis for mine own caſe: I hope you have never 〈◊〉 Cloak for your Knavery, for if you have, you have given me the bag very ſweetly. Exeunt.

div.head: EPILOGƲE; Spoken by Shoomaker.
div.l: IF Bungler-like my Work be brought to end,
I'le be a Cobler, who ye know may mend.
Next time I hope my Work ſhall be more meet,
Now I have learnt the length of all your feet:
But if in Workmanſhip I do excell,
I know your bounty, ye will pay me well.
Or elſe I'le truſt, and book't at your Commands,
So that ye will ſubſcribe it with your Hands.
